abilities: Fire Breathing: Devastating flames from the lion's maw
Triple Threat: Three heads allow attacks from multiple directions
Goat Agility: Mountain goat body provides sure-footedness
Serpent Tail: Venomous strikes from behind
Terrifying Presence: The unnatural combination inspires fear
name: Chimera

christian.overview: The Chimera, with its lion, goat, and serpent components breathing fire, prefigures later Christian iconography of composite beasts representing sin, heresy, or demonic powers. Its defeat by Bellerophon was read as a type of Christ's victory over evil.

biblicalParallels.description: The apocalyptic horses with lion heads and serpent tails that breathe fire echo the Chimera's composite, fire-breathing nature.
Daniel's vision of composite beasts rising from chaos anticipates the Chimera tradition of unnatural combinations representing worldly empires opposed to God.
The peaceable kingdom where predators and prey coexist contrasts with the Chimera's violent fusion, suggesting that sin creates unnatural combinations while redemption restores proper order.

patristicInterpretation.summary: Church Fathers saw the Chimera as representing the disordered passions - multiple drives warring within a single being - overcome only by virtue (Bellerophon on Pegasus representing reason elevated by grace).

sources.author: Fulgentius
sources.interpretation: Interpreted the Chimera allegorically: the lion head represents fierce anger (ira), the goat body represents lustful passion (libido), and the serpent tail represents the sting of consequences (dolus).

sources.author: Isidore of Seville
sources.interpretation: The Chimera represents the stages of human life consumed by passion: youth's fierceness (lion), middle age's sensuality (goat), and old age's cunning (serpent).

medievalSymbolism.bestiaryMeaning: Medieval bestiaries used the Chimera as an example of impossibility and deception - its existence was sometimes denied, seen as a figure for lies that seem real.
medievalSymbolism.moralLesson: The Chimera teaches that sin creates monsters within us - unnatural fusions of conflicting desires that can only be slain by the hero of virtue mounted on the divine Pegasus of grace.
medievalSymbolism.artisticRepresentation: Gothic cathedral sculptures often included chimeric creatures in portrayals of hell and damnation, representing the monstrous transformations wrought by sin.

christian.typologicalReading: Bellerophon's aerial defeat of the Chimera (attacking from above, out of reach of the fire) prefigures Christ's victory from the Cross - striking at sin from a position (the Cross/throne) that sin cannot reach.
